content: Hi, I've been using milestones to mark which version an issue regressed in, which IIUC is how T-release is using them too. But I wanted to double-check that I'm using them correctly. Is that how issues are milestoned?
cc @apiraino since we were discussing this in WG-prioritization
#88586 is an example of an issue I just milestoned, though I mostly do it for rustdoc issues.
It does look like nearly all of the open issues marked with the 1.55.0 milestone are for beta regressions.

I've tried searching in Zulip because this question it's an evergreen around here :-)
Found this comment from @simulacrum , perhaps it helps a little bit
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.20meeting.5D.202020-11-12.20.2354818/near/216481342

and perhaps also this comment (though I don't fully understand it)
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.20meeting.5D.202020-11-12.20.2354818/near/216481232

apiraino said:

and perhaps also this comment (though I don't fully understand it)
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/238009-t-compiler.2Fmeetings/topic/.5Bweekly.20meeting.5D.202020-11-12.20.2354818/near/216481232

I think simulacrum is saying that the PR will land in the release it is milestoned with, but if it's backported, it will also land in an earlier release.
Yes, milestones are issues are "this should be considered when releasing that version", basically
so landed in is the first approximation, sometimes we need to adjust (e.g., if we care enough but it slipped a single release, perhaps)
the incremental issue was like this, where we bumped the milestone several times
Ok, so if a regression-to-{beta,nightly} issue doesn't have a milestone, then it's fine to add one for the release the regression landed in?
I think milestones are also closed when we release, no? then GitHub doesn't let you add issues anymore
we don't need to milestone anything for past releases
they're just better than labels since they define a version and so can be mostly static
I'm assuming "release the regression landed in" would be past though
so the answer to @Noah Lev would be no, milestones can't be used for that
I was referring to when the regression landed in beta or nightly, in which case the milestone is still open.
ah, right, ok
If it's already in stable, it's usually less important to track when it landed.
thanks for the clarifications :thumbs_up:
